RDS we have a service for all the folks who don't want to use relational so it's
called the nosql database which is Dynamo DB and then of course we have our parab scale data warehouse which is red
shift that's been out there since early 2013 was the service we announced at our
first reinvent in uh this time 2012 and then finally our caching service which

style technology vendors you know like IBM and others you know they've been doing this for 30 plus years as anag was

service they've been doing it for 40 years and we have four Services why is it that we're thinking about this in a
different way so the reason is that we think that one size doesn't fit all
today in a connected Social Mobile world where there is tremendous amount of data being generated especially with internet
of things and devices that are connected you know it's just not possible to use
one database for all use cases it really makes you like a jack of all trades a master of none

one to some EX 10 so how do we think about these services and why did we do

that when you take one of these ideas as let's say an engineer on the team and you go see Andy Jesse who's the senior

launched in October of 2009 initially it came out with just my SQL that was the
first engine we supported and then we've added Oracle sequels of our postgress and of course this morning we announced
the new new dawn of databases relational databases with Aurora so so and this is a fully managed
service so why did we do this service you know the obvious answer is duhh you know for the last 30 years every
application has used relational databases it makes sense to have a service and of course even in the future
you know many applications will continue to need relational databases so it makes sense but then if you think a little
harder about it and say well I could always do these things on ec2 because ec2 is a you know our compute platform
you can run any application you can run any code on it so certainly you could run databases and that's where the world
has been and in fact all the people who have created databases but don't use them feel which is pretty much all other
vendors they feel that that's good enough because it's just like any other piece of code that you run on a compute
platform but what is unique about Amazon is since the company was you know startup in July I guess of 1995 which is
going back many years now almost 19 years we have been running databases we
don't only create databases we actually run them and our e-commerce business which is a very large business as all of
you know is you know is a set of applications that use lots and lots of
relational databases and what we learned in uh you know in all the years of running these databases they're really
hard the pain to manage and if you are involved in the IT industry you know
that one of the leading causes for you losing sleep and getting cor L at night
when you were trying to get some sleep is because some database some relational database failed somewhere it's a leading
cause of lost sleep and downtime in the IT world so we said okay yes you could
run relational databases on ec2 but could we do a better job where people get a little more sleep have a little
less downtime and don't have to deal with all the hassles of management with databases that was a core Insight that
we had because of which we built uh Amazon RDS and we built it from the
ground up as a manage service and what we've been able to do is all the mck associated with you know configuring

use an API call or a command line interface and you can say hey magically give me an Oracle database and a few

and we do all the other things like we do the patching we manage the security we back up all your data so that you
know in case of failure of some kind your data is available on S3 to restore from and we do General care and feeding
of databases and what it does for you is it reduces really the total cost of ownership you know in the folks that
manage databases think in terms of dbas number of databases that dbas can manage
and I think when I was talking to the guys at Amazon who've been doing this for a long time you know I guess uh were
Rel relatively speaking pretty good at it and uh we manage like 40 databases
per DBA and uh that gets to be pretty expensive pretty
quickly so so one of the things that Amazon RS does for you is reduces the total cost of ownership and in this way
it makes it cheaper makes it better and generally meets the second tenant that I talked about when we think of new
Services where you know we're making things better but in case of RDS we've gone further than that and we have this
whole thing about built-in High availability and cross region replication it's a it's a feature that
we call Amazon RDS multi-az which allows you to provide much higher availability
than you can get with a single instance database and in fact this is something that maybe as a large company you have
the where withth all to do it especially if you're using a commercial database where they have things like you know
Data Guard and Oracle and SQL server has mirroring and so on which will allow you to do it and if you are a large enough
company where you have multiple data centers you can certainly do it between data centers but if you're a smaller
company uh you know you probably wouldn't be able to do anything like a high availability database without what
we've done with multi-az in fact if you look at it what multi-az does is it gives you Enterprise
grade high availability we give you an SLA of 99.9 95 which means less than 20 minutes or
down time on a monthly basis and the way we do that is that we' have uh done some
features which are not part of stock MySQL we do synchronous replication we do it across our availability zones
which are essentially data centers and we have this amazing amount of technology that we've built over the
last five years which monitors all those databases and figures out all the cases
in which there's a failure detects it automatically flips you over to a
standby database which is running in a different availability zone or in a f fault isolated separate Data Center and
gets your application back running on it so it just quickly does a DNS F over and
your application's up and running it's roughly between 30 to 60 seconds to fail over and after that your application is
continues to run as long as it does the retry on those failures and this is something that uh you know we've had
this is something we introduced in U middle of 2010 and uh since then it's been used
quite a bit and today roughly 40% of a fleet is multi easy which is all the
production use cases we recommend that you use multi easy because in case of any kinds of failures your application
is resilient to them and we're pretty excited about how well it has been adopted by RDS

this service and of course Andy talked about Reinventing the relational database and
I'm going to touch on that a little bit and we'll leave some time at the end for questions I'm sure on Twitter and Hacker

Aurora and I'm going to go into some of the questions that we asked this is going back now three or four years when
we started thinking about this service say if we could really design a database
for the cloud where we said the cloud is a new normal as Andy said and you didn't
have to worry about on premise and worry about you know the old way of doing things and you simply took one

everything else is clean slate what could you do could you provide a database which is amazing in terms of
the performance it provides because it has all of the compute capability and the scale of AWS to leverage did you
provide availability and durability where the durability is indistinguishable from 100%
and of course you're dealing with relational databases so we thought we would take a high goal of
99.99% availability which is four minutes of downtime on a monthly basis as a design goal and said could we do
that and then of course our team went to work on it and what came out three years later
is Amazon Aurora which completely changes the way
databases relational databases have been done over the last 30 years and it's as Andy also mentioned it's significantly
cheaper than what you can get from commercial databases so so it's uh you know as I
mentioned it's a database engine which we have built ourselves it's the only
constraint we've taken is that it's compatible with SQL and in our case we
started with mySQL as the API or as a SQL dialect that we wanted to be compatible with uh and we are offering
commercial grade performance and availability at open Source prices and we retain compatibility with mySQL 56
and we will maintain compatibility with new versions of MySQL as it comes along
uh you know but the production ready version of MySQL that's out there today is
56 and uh let me just quickly highlight some of the things that we mentioned at the keynote but anag talked about this
it's five times the performance in our benchmarks that we've done we've used
you know CIS bench as the you know typical Benchmark that you use with mySQL and
we're able to do 100,000 wrs a second and 5 thou 500,000 reads a second which
is a very big deal and you can do up to 15 Read replicas connected to a single
master and that means that you can do 8 million reads a
second that's a big deal from you know the sorts of things that I've seen in the database world you can take a
database and start out with just 10 gigs which is the smallest database you can get out start with and you don't have to
say anything to us about how you know how you need to scale it you don't have to provision a terabyte if you're using
200 you know gigs and so on we just grow the database as you need to and we can
grow it up to 64 terabytes in the version that is going into preview and I checked around at Amazon to say hey
what's what are some of the big databases that we have and you know some of them are like 12 terabytes because in
the you know databases get pretty big when you're using a data warehouse but when you're using oltp you know the
databases tend to be the biggest databases tend to be in the 10 12 15 terabyte range from what I understand
and we're able to take you to 64 terab so that you know that you don't have to worry about the scale aspect of
databases either from a storage perspective or from IO perspective if you need to do more than
100,000 rights a second which some people may want to do then I'd say
we'll give you a different solution but for that if you want full MySQL compatibility Aurora is the way to go
and the way we achieve this this is something that anra talked about at a little bit of a detail we not only have
innovated in the MySQL engine we've also built purpose built a completely
different virtualized storage layer which is designed for database workloads
essentially what we have done is we've taken the lower half of the database engine if you will which tends to do the
sorts of things that modern virtualized storage services do and essentially tightly couple them so not only have we
built a brand new storage service which is anytime you do a write it wres to all
of the different A's it wres to Three A's do does two copies in every a but it also is tightly coupled with the
database engine so that you reduce the number of iOS that one has to do to get the kind of performance we're talking
about in fact uh with the typical MySQL application or a typical database when you do a write you do a redo log you do
a data page and a bunch of other right so a right gets expanded to something like six rights in our case we reduce
the total number of rights that you have to do to just two so that's what gives us one of the things that gives us the
performance improvements and througho improvements that we're talking about and since we do six-way replication in
three availability zones and uh remind you you that RDS MySQL which or RDS in
general today multi-az does two copies in two A's in this case we're going to Three A's and six
copies and you can have in case of multi-az your standby does not do any
read traffic it's just a standby which sits there till there is an issue of
some kind and then it fails over in this case your standby is actually a read replica you can have 15 of those spread
across three azs and if there's a failure of your master database will
flip over to a stand to a standby read replica if you have one of them if that fails we'll go to a second one we can go
through 16 of them 15 of them before there's an issue for you so it gives you a level of availability which is going
to be at least as good as commercial databases I personally believe that as
you you guys use it in preview you'll find that it goes Way Beyond and all of this without the
expensive cost of you know commercial Enterprise grade databases where not
only you have to pay for those commercial grade databases they're Enterprise version of it but then if you want to get high availability you have
to buy the high availability option none of that here you just start out at a price point as low as 29 cents it's like
you know little more than a quarter if you're going to buy a cup of coffee this morning you could probably buy yourself
a dozen of these for an hour and just spin them up so it's it's it's pretty inexpensive
and pretty powerful we're super excited about what the team has done over the last 3 4 years as we have built
this okay so who should use RDS Aurora because Aurora is an engine
it's part of RDS and our view is that if you are a MySQL user you should use aora
it's going to be going into preview so if you're running production applications of course those you would run till we are in preview in on MySQL
stock Edition which is community Edition but after that you should be able to move all of those applications to Aurora
and if you're designing a new application and you want the commercial grade performance and availability you
should use Aurora all right so that's about
relational databases and RDS and how we think about those and how over the last five years we've come from starting with
the service that started as my SQL and then taking it all the way to Reinventing the database let me talk a

give you a little bit of an insight as to how we thought about it let me start with a little bit of a history of uh no
SQL at Amazon I guess the way the The Story Goes is that and I wasn't here at
the time at Amazon but in 2004 in our busy Christmas season where we make a
lot of our money as a retailer in the e-commerce space our databases which
were running on Oracle rack I believe decided to go down and we had an outage for I
think number of hours and we lost millions of dollars and after that Jeff called wner who's our CTO and said hey
man you got to have a better database next time around you got a year to figure this out because Christmas is
going to come around next year and I don't want to have this issue so he went to work with a number of people that are
you know that were part of team Swami and a bunch of other folks and they came up with a new kind of technology which
really in some ways is the start of the nosql segment or movement in terms of
building highly scalable highly available databases and the issue we were having was we were running our
business in 2004 at a scale that relational databases just couldn't scale
to and they couldn't give you the kind of availability that we needed for our business and they wrote a very famous
paper based on the research that we did uh in 2004 and 5 which is uh you know
something that all distributed systems Engineers read it's a Dynamo paper and
that really laid out many of the concepts that have become the basis for a lot of the nosql stores you know
Cassandra is based on it there are many other products in the market which are open source products that are based on
those Concepts and we took the same Concepts when we started to build Dynamo DB in um you know we launched Dynamo DB
in January of 2012 it was multi-year effort prior to that and again in terms of the quick key questions we asked was
well you know we were thinking about doing Aurora at the time and say okay in Aurora we're taking a constraint which
is called SQL so we're going to say yes to SQL for Aurora what if we say no to SQL which is take no constraints at all
complete clean SL slate of paper sheet of paper so no SQL not a SQL became no
SQL and uh we said what could we do could we eliminate the things that even
after an amazing database like Aurora comes out you're going to say I wish those constraints were not there could
we make it better in ways that relational could never do and what we have been able to do to
Dynamo DB is that we give you a scale seamless scale Beyond where a single box
can scale so in case of Aurora if you don't want to Shard and sharding is not transparent to the application you can
go up to R38 XL which is the largest instance we can give you and on that one you can do 100,000 wres and 500,000
reads certainly you can scale reads using read replicas but wres without charting you have no choice we have
customers who do way more than 100,000 rights a second there are applications
that need that we have one customer that does close to a million wres a second
that's the kind of database they need so we felt that for something like that Dynamo DB is the answer because what
Dynamo DB does is because it doesn't have the constraint of SQL and relational semantics it's able to Shard
your data and your tables behind the scenes and give you as much IO as you want all you do is it's completely
schema less all you do is you start out and give us a table create a table and you just start writing to it and you can
start out by saying I want 10 writes and 10 reads because I'm just testing my application and when it comes day to
launch you can dial that up to a million reads and writes and we'll just keep on chugging
and the other thing that is unique about Dynamo DB which is hard to do with relational is the predictable
performance you know there are many of us who deal with relational databases and it's running really well and in the
morning when you come in you find that you know there's some kind of Hiccup your queries are running slow because
there's more data in the system there's something that happened and your query Optimizer decided it's going to do some
kind of cost bait cost based optimization which it didn't quite do it the way it should and your queries are
running slow and you're running around trying to figure out why are my queries running slow and diagnosing why
application is coming down none of this happens with Dynamo DV because we give you predictable
performance and latencies which are in the single millisecond single digit milliseconds and we just no matter how
many iOS you want how many users are using your application your database continues to give you the same kind of a
performance and it does all of this along with giving you availability was
indistinguishable from 100% so this this database gives you more than
99.99% availability and there's no notion of failovers so there's not this issue which happens with the relational
databases that in case of a failover it takes you 30 to 60 Minutes to fail over your application from a master to a
slave which becomes a new master in this case this is completely transparent so these are some of the things that we are
able to do because we removed the constraint of uh relational semantics
and uh there's as I mentioned there's nothing to manage you simply there's not even a notion of an instance it's just a
multi-tenant service you just create a table and you just keep writing to it and the table doesn't have a schema so
you can have items or rows with whatever you want in them and with the latest release of uh Dynamo DB we are not only
a key value store which is what it started out in early 2012 when we launched it uh it's become both a key
value store and a document store it's supp Json objects natively and it does
queries against not only the primary key but also against your secondary key so you can have secondary indices and you
can do queries against all of them which at scale is a fairly hard problem so it took us two more years since we launched
the original product to make that available in uh early
2014 so let me talk a little bit about the latency that I mentioned here's a graph from um our Fleet as a number of

much read is more important for databases in today's world I think it's going to change with internet of things where people are going to write more
than they'll read Because machines write more than they read but in the human world reading is more important and
therefore caching is critical for all databases and we felt that just like we had done for RDS it would make sense for
us to do inmemory caching service that was fully managed has been you know very
well adapted we started out with mcash d and um last year in SE cember we

is a gaming company in Japan that uses it GRE is a gaming platform in Japan that uses it and many many other
companies like Airbnb which is amazing startup and uh finally let me take a few
minutes to talk about Amazon uh Amazon red shift which is our parab scale data
warehouse this is something we launched in February of 2013 for production use case it's been something that you know
was available in preview starting at reinvent our very first reinvent in 2012 so it's been available for production
use case for about 20 months it's it's uh it's I'm going to go into all the details with it and it's one of our
fastest growing services and there are number of people that are using it super excited about it both in terms of what
customers are doing it and how well it's growing and we when we built it you know we launched it in early 2013 it was
again a multi-year effort for us we said you know what's the reason for building a
data warehouse like red shift and the thing that was really interesting at that time was that we had a customer was
a pretty big customer of ours and they were generating uh terabytes of data you
know tens of terabytes of data every day and they had no way of analyzing it because there was no data warehouse
available and they were taking it from the cloud back to on premise and they
were running one of those old data warehouses expensive data warehouses analyzing it then bringing it the
results back to their application running on AWS and we thought that was kind of backwards make no sense to have
the data be born in the cloud and then have to go to the on premise just because such a service wasn't available
and then we had one many other customers one of them who said look I've moved everything to AWS I'm 100% in I just
have one service running on premise which is my data warehouse and I can't
shut down my data center till you give me a service like that and through us that was a good enough reason to do it
and then when we said okay we're going to do something in the space then we asked the two questions that that you know I highlighted initially what are
you going to do that people couldn't do before and how are you going to make
people's lives better and here's the key Insight that drove this for us so the
key Insight was that today there's a lot of data being generated if you look at any company you know only roughly 10% of
the data that they have access to is being analyzed rest of is literally being thrown on the floor because it's
just too hard to build a data warehouse that could be at a scale to analyze 100%
of your data and could be at a cost where you could justify to your boss that hey this data that I have really
has a Roi on it for me to really use it so we said well could we build a service
where you didn't have to think about the complexity as being a issue or the cost
being an issue so that if you had data which had some value to you you could use it and that's where we that was
really the key design point for us in terms of what we did and he said we will
leverage the massive scale of the cloud to give you something
that was so scalable and so cheap that you could analyze all your data and what we ended up building which
was a multi-year exercise because this is a complicated data warehousing system
uh behind the scenes is that we decided to build what is known in the industry as a MPP system massively parallel
processing architecture where you can take a system which starts out with a single database node and scale it up
today we can scale it up to 128 nodes and this is all behind the scenes there's no it's completely transparent
to your application to the application it just looks like a postest compatible SQL end point and behind the scenes it
scales and uh so that we could give you the massive scalability that you could
do and you can do a single cluster with two terabytes of data uh and this is
something where we built it as a column store instead of traditional data warehouses which historically have been
built as row stores because queries happen across a column so if you store your data in the
column major format you're able to reduce the number of iOS it takes you to do the query which increase the
performance and and the way we priced it is at $1,000 a terabyte if so those of
you who are familiar with data warehouses know that the cheapest data warehouses usually run $10,000 a
